Edit* Unfortunately, after checking for spelling errors, etc, I realized the formatting is not the greatest on Google Play. While breaking lines  with the enter key, I learned that it did not work. Please bear with the wall of text. Due to the character limit on Google Play, this will be brief. Yes, the controls are awkward to get used to, but efficient, fantastic when you understand their use, and easy to understand. The requirement for internet is annoying, but not part of the actual game, so I'm ignoring that. Besides. It's a great game, best played when you have full immersion. So you shouldn't be playing it when you can't play anything else anyway.  Now onto the game itself. From the NES release, it's gotten much less grindy, but still takes some effort. Square has hit a perfect balance. The world is fun to explore, there are many secrets, optional content, and so much is explained with so little phrases. You understand the world, the direction is fantastic, and you actually have to think about what to do. It's not mindless, and that's amazing! The only real issue I have with it is how easy it is to win. It's not hard to fix either, just numbers.  Spoilers ahead.  Enemies only need more health and more attacks. Kraken has used a grand total of two attacks against me. All it took to counter it was NulFrost and Protera. Or one cast from my Knight and White Wizard each. Then a mere three turns off attacks and Thundaga casts wiped it without me even needing to heal. This was at level 33 for clarification. Tiamat was even easier than this. Which is so unfortunate, because I remember having to prepare, and attempt the Marsh Caves multiple times even after I prepared, which made me love this world so much more: it was unforgiving, dangerous, and even if you were chosen heroes, you still faced risk.  Spoilers over.  Another balancing issue is the Thief. Promoted class as Ninja. Yes, they're strong, but you could pick a Monk/Master, who has more health, more Evasion, more damage, and is cheaper to equip. The sacrifice is that they can't use Black magic, but is that even necessary when you have a white, black, and red mage to pick from?  Overall, the game provides an amazing experience where you put yourself in the shoes of the hero(s), experiencing growth, and watching progression, discovering a world. This is somewhat mitigated by the awkward use of controls, but those only last the first hour of the game, which is hardly any time at all.   And fortunately, due to the class selection, and ability to do things in almost any order from the get go, there is so much replay value. You can forge your own stories and relationships between the Characters you make in your head, which is just a huge beauty of open world games, which I would consider this.  But is it worth it? If Square made this into a remastered HD version, 3D Models, Voice Acting, and an improved soundtrack, I would, without a doubt, buy it for the full price of a Triple A title. In fact, I hope a remastered edition of that calibur comes out, so I can experience this again in an even more immersive fashion than before. *Hint, hint, nudge, nudge.  Keep up the good work, Square.

The Android version of the game does not include ANY of the Dawn of Souls content that has been included in every release including the iOS version for the last 15 years. This is pathetic. If you want to play all the content available for this game, either buy the iOS version, the DS version or better yet demand better service from the developer by not buying it at all. I love FF1. Have played it many times... but I'm sorely disappointed in this release of it!  For one, it seems like the bonus dungeons have been removed... which is odd, considering that they'd likely have had to work to remove it during the port process. I was pretty angry to find this out AFTER the fact -- I was all leveled up and ready to tackle the challenge, but for nothing. Jerks.  I'm also quite annoyed with the controls. It seems like an excessive amount of taps are required to do anything, and I would rather have just played the game on an emulator. For example, using an item or casting a spell that effects all enemies or allies requires yet another tap -- just use the dang thing! -- and that's after several taps just to get to the item. There should have been a "repeat last action" button...  Another annoyance, but minor: the music in the game is a perfect loop, and always has been. But, instead of just restarting to loop, they have it fade out slowly after some time, then BAM, starts over again at full volume, but not in sync...  It's still a classic, and worth the few bucks if you haven't played it before.

So, I love Final Fantasy, it was a staple of my childhood, and being able to play it with the re-release graphics and soundtrack is wonderful.  It runs pretty well on my system (Samsung Galaxy S3) although it does lag occasionally.  The downsides:  First, the game checks your license every single time you start it.  Which stinks if you're somewhere you can't get internet access, such as a subway tunnel.  Second, it handles interruptions from other apps very, very poorly.  Anything that interrupts it, such as a calendar reminder, shuts the game down entirely, necessitating a reboot.  The quicksave feature saves this from being catastrophic, since it automatically quicksaves when interrupted, but if you were in the middle of combat, the game does not save this fact and you will resume standing on the map where the encounter occurred.  I just hope that doesn't cause anything catastrophic if I happen to get a phone call while in a scripted battle.  When problems 1 and 2 combine, it really sucks because you get booted out of your game and aren't allowed to start it up again.
